qas.question: When did King Richard I begin his reign?
Which animal is the main motif of England's national football team?
What type of headgear originally appeared on the lions' heads on England's national football team motif?
In which year was the FA given an official coat of arms by the College of Arms?
Since 2003, England has topped their logo with a star to recognize their World Cup win in which year?
In what year was King Richard I born?
Where is the English logo currently embroidered on their shirts?
What colour are the ten Tudor roses on England's shirts?
In what year was the College of Arms established?
Who established the College of Arms?

context: The motif of the England national football team has three <a1_0>lions<a1_0/> passant guardant, the emblem of <b9_0>King Richard I<b9_0/>, who reigned from <a0_0><b5_0><b8_0>1189<b8_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/> to 1199. The lions, often <b7_0>blue<b7_0/>, have had minor changes to colour and appearance. Initially topped by <a2_0>a crown<a2_0/>, this was removed in <a3_0>1949<a3_0/> when the FA was given an official coat of arms by the College of Arms; this introduced ten Tudor roses, one for each of the regional branches of the FA. Since 2003, England top their logo with a star to recognise their World Cup win in <a4_0>1966<a4_0/>; this was first embroidered onto the <b6_0>left sleeve<b6_0/> of the home kit, and a year later was moved to its current position, first on the away shirt.
